participants.participant: Peter Löscher, President and Chief Executive Officer
Joe Kaeser, Head of Corporate Finance and Controlling

plist.p: So good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen, and to those watching our webcast. It's my pleasure to welcome you to this afternoon for our second quarter analyst conference. The earnings release, the Flashlight and all other documents were published at 7 a.m. CET this morning. You can download these files from our website.

This afternoon's presentation is now online and the conference is being webcast via the IR website. I would like also refer you to our Safe Harbor statement on page two of the presentation. Our President and CEO, Peter Löscher; and our CFO, Joe Kaeser, are here this afternoon to present the Q2 results.
After presentation we will have a Q&A session where Peter and Joe will answer your questions. So with that I would like to hand over to Peter.

Thank you very. Good afternoon to everybody, another solid quarter and robust operating performance. I will start off going through the highlights of the quarter, Joe will follow with the financial details, and I will close with the guidance for the full year before we take your questions.

First our order picture, year-on-year orders slipped 14%, impacted mostly by further market contraction in the long-cycle activities in Industry and Energy. However, the comparison with the last quarters – with the last year's quarter is actually tough due to some very large orders, which happened in the second quarter 2009; I just remind you a large order in mobility, large orders in fossil.

Compared to the drop in orders total sector revenues were slightly down by 4% versus last year, but up sequentially against Q1. This shows how hard we are pushing to convert our backlog. The stabilization of our business is led by the recovery in our short cycle divisions and growth in emerging markets. Profits were stronger, up 16% versus prior year and every sector is in the target margin range. Again, here the diligent backlog conversion is key as is the rigorous control on costs across the company. The stronger earnings combined with rigorous discipline to CapEx and working capital management is reflected in our strong cash flow figures.

Driven by the market demand we adjust our resource base further. We have announced workforce adjustments in our Industry Solutions, Right Technologies and Siemens IT divisions. Our strong execution and stabilizing end markets leads us to a favorable assessment of continuing profit development. Therefore, we are increasing our profit guidance for the year, which I will touch upon later.

Let's first look at the figures. I have already laid out the orders and revenue highlights. Book-to-bill was close to one with 0.98, despite being below one we feel that in the context to the market environment this is a very solid result. When looking at our sales funnel, the order situation across the company is showing stabilization. All sectors contributed to the excellent total sector profit of 2.1 billion and the margin of 12.3%.

The sectors benefited from €118 million positive effect due to the curtailment of the U.S. pension plans that were partially offset by 125 million in restructuring charges mainly in Fossil and Industry Solutions. Lower cost below the sectors help to raise net income by 48% to 1.5 billion and basic earnings per share was €1.70.

Turning next to our order backlog, it continues to be a source of stability and strength; end of the quarter it stood at a very solid €84 billion, slightly up from 83 billion at the end of the first quarter, mainly due to currency changes. To demonstrate a few highlights of the quarter, Industry recorded a €450 million order to supply components to Chinese inter-city trains, underlying our strategy in the region.

In Energy, we won a 435-megawatt combined cycle power plant in the Netherlands and our technological leadership in high efficient gas turbines was a crucial factor in winning this order. Meanwhile, we continue our global flow of orders in our renewable division with, for example, an order for 60 onshore turbines in Canada.

With this, the order backlog at renewables is at an excellent level of €7 billion at the end of the quarter. And in healthcare, we were able to book our largest single order in the Middle East, US$69 million imaging equipment order for around 100 hospitals in Iraq to rebuild healthcare services. This included an attractive 5-year service contract.

Let's take a closer look at the sector performance in the quarter starting with Industry. The Industry sector was the first sector to be affected by the downturn. It is now showing the first signs of a stable recovery. Unfortunately, we still see low investment activity in the late-cycle businesses, such as at metals, Technologies and Industry Solutions.

But there's clearly a traction in the recovery of our short-cycle businesses that goes beyond restocking, especially in emerging markets. An excellent example of the turnaround was Industry Automation, which not only benefited from a disciplined cost management, but also strong demand from the emerging markets.

We continue to see support at our short-cycle businesses and Industry Automation is turning, which is also backed up by recent actually today – by today's VDMA data of sequentially plus 21% and showing a marked turnaround in machinery orders. But we also have to bear in mind that a year ago we were talking about the decline of minus – of over minus 40%, so there's obviously a base effect as well.

OSRAM continues to benefit from the combined effects of strong demand for LEDs, which in Q2 accounts for 18% of OSRAM sales, and the seasonal strength of lighting during the first half. Also the demand from automotive customers showed an impressive rebound. The margin of mobility at 8% is an excellent result and puts us in a very good position compared to our peers.

In addition, the sales funnel remains strong as we have recently seen by the 1 billion frame contract for 200 regional passenger trains ordered by the Austrian Federal Railways. Building Technologies was able to show order growth driven by strong demand from emerging countries, more than offsetting continued weakness, especially in the non-residential U.S. market.
However, profitability at BT was held back by supplier-related product warranty charge that was somewhat compensated by the pension gain.

As already mentioned, the Industry Solutions end markets in the process industries remain challenging. A disappointment was the 63 million charge due to a U.S. project with a local partner. We have taken immediate action to mitigate these risks and believe the situation is under control. In addition, we've booked 38 million charges for capacity adjustments in Industry Solutions. We will see more of that in the coming quarters in IS and Drive Technologies.

Now moving on to Energy, orders were lower year-over-year, partly due to the lumpy order inflow from renewables. In addition, we continue to operate in an environment that can best be described, as we have already said since several quarters, as a Mexican stand-off.

Following the drop off in industrial production, the utility companies still have excess generation capacity and therefore requesting lower prices. The suppliers, on the other hand, still have a full order book and know that the utilities will need to upgrade their facilities. Now it will depend on who will blink first.

That said, the order book still stands at €50 billion in Energy alone, and delivered a solid almost one book-to-bill ratio with 0.98, and despite the weakness in orders revenue continued to hold up, down just 4%, and the sector produced excellent margins, thanks to our, to an order backlog with healthy margins, good project execution and disciplined cost control. Within the Fossil division, we took decisions to improve the operating structure by shifting gas turbine production from Hamilton, Canada to Charlotte, North Carolina, which resulted in a 59 million charge for severance and relocation efforts.

Despite this charge, all divisions reported margins well within their target range, helped by strong product mix, including services, particularly in fossil power generation and oil and gas. Renewables has reported all-time-high revenues in Q2 and profitability has rebounced from Q1. Orders were down year-on-year due to large off-shore orders last year, but based on our active sales funnel in on and offshore, we expect the book-to-bill ratio well above 1 in the second half.

In transmission and distribution, profits were solid but we still see pricing pressure, mainly in the transformer and medium-voltage area. However, we are seeing early signs of a market recovery as distribution was able to show a positive order intake for the first time in more than a year.

A clear positive for the health care sector was the final passage of the U.S. healthcare reform. After many months of uncertainty, we welcome the clarity that this has on our business and our customers and are looking to move on actively growing our sales going forward also in the United States.

Overall sector orders were up 1%. However, this is due to the large particle therapy order in the previous year period, and excluding this effect, orders were up 6%, imaging and IT were able to report an 8% order growth driven by Asia, which was up 27% in the quarter.

Margins were helped by a 79 million positive pension effect for the healthcare sector and favorable currency hedging, especially at imaging and IT. Imaging and IT continues to lead the divisions in profitability, with a strong service business, positive product mix and tight cost control.

Diagnostics saw an improved revenue growth of 5% organically, driven by growth in Asia and the Americas. Higher sales dropped through to the bottom line and underlying profits were supported by tight cost management, which led to an underlying margin of 17.7%.

Now I think it's important to turn to topics which actually drive sales and innovation. I would like to show here on this chart three examples of key innovations for the futures. I have selected three examples here. On the left hand side you can see an example from OSRAM; we are now supplying the OD8 as the first volume vehicle to have all LED forward lighting. Not only does this save energy but it also improves driver safety with clear free driving.

In the middle you see, you have an example of renewable. We are pioneering here as well new technologies. Here is our 3-megawatt gearless turbine with a 101-meter rotor diameter. The gearless construction means 50% fewer parts and fewer rotating parts leads to lower maintenance costs and increased availability for our customers. This is a great example of collaboration between Industry and Energy. The innovative generator comes from our large drives unit.

In healthcare, on the right hand side, we have introduced at the last RSNA the next generation of MIs, the MAGNETOM Aera and Skyra, and these scanners are at the forefront in imaging technology and orders are flowing in. Its dramatically improved speed and image quality opens up new applications for MR, for example in cardiology. These are just a few examples of our innovation leadership. We will drive growth through a steady stream of innovation.
And with this I would like to hand over to Joe.

Thank you very much, Peter. A very warm welcome to all of you to Canary Wharf. We really do appreciate you coming in those turbulent macroeconomic times and listen to us as a humble industrial company in Germany. So that's actually good.

And let me start with our financial cockpit on a corporate level. As you know we've rolled out a few financial targets for our company to be achieved in the 2010, which is now, so we are just about to finish also the goal line for our 2010 program. If I may draw your attention to the upper left part here on profitability, Peter said it already, all these sectors are within our target margin, and if our market assumptions prevail, there is also a good chance that we see the sectors to stay within that range by year end.

Second topic on the upper right is the cash conversion rate, we are still a very strong believer that the reported earnings also need to come in as cash at some point and especially given from our strong performance, relatively strong performance, in fiscal Q1, we are actually very satisfied with our cash conversion rate in fiscal Q2, which is 0.84, so getting reasonably close to our target, which says 1 minus growth rate.

As far as capital structure is concerned, it is on the lower left, that's probably one of the few areas where we failed to make good on what our targets were. But in all honesty, that's not necessarily concerns me very much because a solid capital structure these days definitely helps the company coming through difficult times in terms of market volatility and financial markets.

So, as you know, we measure our capital structure as industrial net debt over EBITDA, supposed to be between 0.8 and 1.0 and we unintendedly reached that goal in fiscal 2009 and now we are back at 0.35, which is probably a little more comfortable than we were planning for – but there is nothing wrong with that. So we will be also in 2010 most likely below the 0.8 to 1.0. But then again we do not believe this is major problem and we can help it quickly if we wanted to.

As far as the capital efficiency is concerned, which for us is one of the most meaningful numbers that we manage the company with, and that's the return on capital employed. Our target margin has been 14 to 16%, and if you look at the return on capital employed numbers quarter-by-quarter, especially also 2009 and 2008, where we were reasonably charged with the transformation cost.

Now in 2010 it begins to pay off. We've been showing solid capital efficiency rates at about 15%. Now I would not suggest that this 15% is going to stay for all year 2010, but we will be disappointed if we are far below the target range in capital efficiency.

Now let me turn your attention to why we believe we've been making progress in most aspects we have been looking into and we have been active on. In terms of working capital and CapEx management, the working capital turns, which you see on the left side of that chart, it's just about the levels of what we had last year in the same quarter, so we're turning out working capital as to our definition, which is also displayed on our internet, 8.1 times on an annualized base, and that's pretty much what we have also seen in Q2.

We have sourced some critical key components a little more than we probably would have done in normal times because we do see some squeezing on semiconductor components, electrical components, environments that we do not want to take the risk that we are shy of more than 4.5% of the bill of materials and not being able to deliver what is being needed in our markets. So that may slightly effect our performance improvements going forward. But an area of 8.5 to 8.8 for the whole year is definitely something which we believe is reasonably well achievable.

As far as CapEx spending is concerned, we've probably as you know been one of the first ones to put the brakes on that one, following our organic order growth, which obviously is a key milestone on how to manage CapEx. You see our CapEx rate, which we define as CapEx divided by depreciation, pretty much follows the organic order intake graphs in this particular aspect blue follows red.

And we've been pretty low with 58% in fiscal Q2; that does not mean that we are not investing into our business any more, it just means that we have already ordered most of our equipment which is being needed for 2011 based on the lead times, and we do expect the CapEx rate to be a little below or maybe at the lower range of our target range of 95 to 115 going forward.

Now on the free cash flow, as already mentioned, we do feel comfortable with our free cash flow in Q2, especially given the Q1 performance. If you compare the seasonality of the free cash flow development over time, it's been obviously pretty seasonal here, and if we look at the current graph on 2010, there is obviously still seasonality, but we've managed to make it less volatile in the first half of fiscal 2010.

Now obviously, the question is, will we still have seasonality for the second half and how much would that be? That mostly depends on how we do in our environment of prepayments and billings in excess. I mentioned few quarters ago already that we see some trend, which in a way was alarming, because after many, many quarters so far steep increase of customer prepayments and increase of billing in excess, which means financing by our customers more or less, you see that on the blue graph here, blue curve.

We saw some reasonably steep change in trend from fiscal Q1 2009 all the way till Q4 2009, the last two quarters it seems that we have some pick-up again, but that has been related mostly to billings in excess. So we still do believe with our working hypothesis that the long-cycle business, the late-cycle business, still continue to slide in order intake. We would actually expect that these positive seasonality on free cash flow for the second half of our fiscal year will be less steep than it used to be in prior years.

Now so far it probably was more easy to digest matters, probably going through the more crucial point of your attention, if I'm not completely mistaken, and that is the development what we call below the total sector line, which has actually been reasonably favorable for two quarters in a row, much more favorable than the overall real situation in the company exists. We do have seen those positive developments now also in Q2, however, that's been materially impacted by non-sustainable positive one-offs, and I'll came to that while we go through the items.

On the left hand side you see how the items have develop in Q2 from total sector profit of 2.1 – 38 million all the way down to a solid 1.5 net income from continued operations. The equity investments, predominantly NSN, remain a challenge. They've been reasonably positive because we have not yet materially received the impact of the already announced restructuring plans of NSN. As you know, we have an agreement with the managing shareholder that they will do the financial guidance, as they also consolidate the numbers in the books, and there has been an announcement in January on material restructuring, has not come through yet, is expected to be of material impact in the second half of 2010.

The positive here on NSN is definitely that they are back in the market. They have proven a good standing on fourth generation network competitiveness, they've won a series of good orders on LTE. However, as far as profitability is concerned, we still expect improvements to come forward.

SIS with minus 10 already shows the expected weakness, but as you know we have announced a significant structural items to bring the IT and software competency back to the company, which we believe is important. Also not only for SIS, but also for vertical units in the company, and actions and strategies are on their way.

But also in SIS obviously is the 4,200 job cuts, which we have announced last quarter, will take their toll in fiscal Q2 in terms of restructuring in the second half of 2010 – in terms of restructuring. We would expect the restructuring to come earliest in fiscal Q4, but we will book it as it arrives. That means when all the requirements of IFRS are being met that means also that there is an agreement with the workers council on how to deal with the matter going forward.

So you might also recall that we have announced a carve-out of the SIS and make it a separate company, being able to follow all the particular aspects of an IT company that also will be associated with a material number of carve-out costs in the second half of 2010 to make it a standalone dedicated company of its own.

SFS has had another extraordinary quarter, almost 100 million of profit, similar number we've seen already in Q1. I mean this is a financial company and it has not had to deal with all the adverse impacts of this sector and I do not expect that to happen also in fiscal – in the second half of 2010. However, I would not expect SFS to be at the same level as what we have seen in the first half of 2010, which was exceptional.

The next item is the so-called centrally managed portfolio assets, predominantly our pick and place business, which we have taken out of the drive technology division and fix it up to create value, and there is not really a material change to our estimate, which we have given in our guidance in December. We do see clearer of what needs to be done. We do see that the market also has recovered somewhat, so there is potentially an upside to what we have given in December. However, it's too early to call, so therefore just bear with the estimate we have given in that particular item.

Corporate items and pensions were very favorably impacted by positive one-offs, which were related to the settlements with the insurance on D&O and also the recovery of money related to the compliance aspects of the company, and that altogether amounted to an amount of about 130 million in Q2, which obviously is not going to be back in the second half in 2010. So that definitely contributed to a very favorable corporate item aspect.

Going forward, if you put about a €400 million into your quarterly model, you're probably going to be on the safe side, okay. Pension, obviously it's harder to call because that depends mostly on the interest rate development, which can serve as a discount factor for the future obligations, so that could go either way. That's also true by the way for the so-called asset retirement obligation, which we have for several years to come, that also could go either way, so we have not put any price tag on that matter, neither to the positive nor to the negative.

Accessory was quite a decent result with 107 million, that mostly stems from the fact that we have sold an asset, bigger asset in Munich, which contributed about 80 million to the bottom line; so also a positive one-off. As you know, we always make clear we are trying to dissolve of the assets and then leased them back for the time being to make sure that even long-term fixed cost assets eventually became a more variable component to adjust to needs if they came.

Corporate Treasury and other items, again about 100 million run rate a quarter is probably something to be comfortable with going forward. So all in all if I may summarize what we expect for the second half of 2010, there is no reason to be overly optimistic on those items. We are working harder and we are making progress in many aspects, so there is little downside to what I said, and there is also from today's point of view there are limited upside, or too early to tell on those particular aspects.
And with that, ladies and gentlemen, I will give it back to Peter to summarize and comment on the guidance which we have given as a company. Thank you.

Thank you, Joe. Let me just summarize once more the economic picture as we see today. There is without any doubt that we see early-cycle businesses coming back. We have leading indicators who are pointing towards a positive direction. And we also have to bear in mind that that's a stark reminder these days that we are still living in a volatile environment and plus as a major industrial company. It's also very important that we remind ourselves that last year we didn't just see a decrease in global GDP, but more importantly we saw a reduction in the industrial global GDP by minus 9%.

So we are living in a world despite positive factors, and the VDMA's is a great example of this, with the reporting their plus 21% quarter-on-quarter of low capacity utilization in many of our key end markets, which currently are at the level of roughly 70-plus percent. And the reinvestment level is somewhere between 80 plus, before actually our customers decide on new investments. But without any doubt, we also have clearly a better visibility than we use to have a couple of months ago. And against this backdrop we have moved up, and I think it was not any surprise to you, our guidance for 2010 and our profit expectation. We clearly want to actually achieve at least an operating profit at the sector level and surpassing the profit that we have seen last year.

We see organic growth being down in the mid-to-single digit range due to in part the stabilizing effect of our strong order backlogs, so no change. And thanks to the improved business situation in our markets, we also expect correspondingly to raise our target for income from continuing operations after tax in the same proportion as we anticipate that the sector profit would move up.
And with this I would like to open it up for any type of questions that you may have. Thank you.
Okay. Let's start with James Stettler.

Yes. Thank you. Can you talk a bit about restructuring charges for the rest of the year, what areas and what amounts? And in terms of second half of the year, can you also talk a bit about how you see pricing development versus the original target, and indeed what kind of raw material headwind we should expect in the second half?

Yeah. James, let me start with the restructuring cost that is not really a change to our estimate. We expect about a 500 million roughly on the total sector environment, and that comes in many of the sectors, and about 500 million roughly below the sector, which obviously is predominantly in the SIS environment. But then again we consider the restructuring when we have agreements on the already announced areas, and everything also of course will depend on market conditions. We have seen some signs of improvement in the market, so we closely follow the situation, so about 500 above and 500 below. No change in our estimate so far. And if there was that level of restructuring it would likely be mostly Q4 rather than in the maturity in Q3.

Now on the pricing, I mean, that probably your question went two ways, first, is the pricing from our suppliers and commodities and the like, and secondly of course also on the top line. You may have realized when we published our guidance and the papers, the footnotes you know in the fine print on what is meant and what is not considered in a guidance, it was lacking the sentence that the -we still expect some rough time on guidance and some downside on the pricing; that one has gone away. So we feel reasonably comfortable about not having any additional pricing pressure going forward.

Also to a material extent our assumption that currency and lack of capacity of fulfillment utilization would trigger additional capacity pressure has also gone away. That in part also made us raise the guidance for 2010. So there's been quite a disciplined pricing environment in Industry, except parts of Industrial Solutions in particular the metals environment, which has become very price sensitive. Definitely has not been led by us, but obviously we need to consider market conditions.

There is also some weakness, some pocket of weakness in the sale – in the order funnel of Fossil, in part also on on-shore wind. And, as Peter has already mentioned, also positive bookings in parts of . But still there is no irrational exuberance at this point in time from the competitive environment, so we feel reasonably positive about the pricing going forward.

On the commodity method, I mean, of course this is not always subject to demand only, but also on who is short and who is long and who has got the power of negotiation. And if you look into, for example, in the iron ore environment there has been quite an increase in aggressiveness on how the partners interact with each other. We've hedged everywhere we were able to hedge, okay. In Q1 already in Q2, so in terms of commodities, which have market pricing and which we are able and in a position to secure, we have done it.
But that doesn't necessarily mean that there would not be upward pressure on some commodity environments if and when they go up further.
Okay.
So next Peter Reilly, Deutsche Bank

Good afternoon. Peter Reilly from Deutsche Bank. Three questions please, starting with workflow and solutions and especially with hearing aids, the performance here seems to be deteriorating according to the press you decided not to exit the business. One of the lessons I think from the whole mobile phone issue is that if you are in a business where the value is shrinking it's better to exit sooner rather than later. So can you give us an update on your thinking there?

Secondly in Fossil Power, another very good margin performance and you mentioned the strength of service. You've mentioned in the past the margin, the backlog being very high quality. How durable is this higher margin performance in Fossil Power? Are we seeing a new level of profitability based on change mix or is that something that's going to fade as we go through the year?

Then lastly on OSRAM, a very encouraging growth rate and you mentioned LEDs are now 18%. The margin slipped slightly from the very strong first quarter. I'm just wondering what the impact of the rising LED proportion does to the margin of OSRAM, whether it's an inherently higher or lower margin business, given that that part of the OSRAM seems to be growing very strongly?

All right. If I start with the hearing aids business, I mean, A, we have made the decision that we continue to manage this business. This continues to be a good business, excellent margin performance and we just put a new manager, a new CEO, in place who knows the industry and the business extremely well, and we are confident and comfortable that we will continue to drive value in this business.

On Fossil and on the exit quite frankly, we have received some bids, we have received values but we have come to the conclusion that actually we ourselves are able to drive the value equation better versus what we have seen what third parties were willing to offer us at this moment, and this is why we continue to drive it ourselves.

On fossil power, as I said earlier in my presentation, and I said it already a couple of quarters ago, this is a classic Mexican stand-off. We continue to have a very solid and strong order backlog and order book. I mean, out of the 50 billion what we seen in Energy we're 25 billion in fossil. The quality, the price quality is good in there, and so we feel quite comfortable.

But, nevertheless, I mean there is no question that the pricing expectations of our customers are coming down, rightfully so I would say and, therefore, as Joe has highlighted, we are continuing to drive supply chain measures, productivity measures to really make sure that we are able to be competitive from a pricing perspective, but also continue to keep the margin quality what we've seen in this business.

Yeah. Also one more on Fossil Power on the backlog with Energy, we not only have good pricing quality there's also good margin quality, so you can expect the current backlog to be just about at, if not slightly above, the current gross margin achievement, so it is as mostly in that particular business, it's all about execution.

We also have a decent change in the mix between solution and products. In fossil, the product content has gone up from about 30 to 38, which is a positive for the merchant, but adds some balance to capital efficiency, as you will know, of course, the model is a bit different in terms of customer pre-payments. So it's all about the balance, but it's reasonably well contained in the backlog. We could talk about pricing and more heated debate between supplier and customer that leads to the order funnel rather than to the backlog itself.

On the topic of solution you may recall that just about a year ago almost, we said that there's got to be some structural realignment of the division. You may have heard the news this morning that we have actually said that there will be news here soon. It's not going to be spectacular, or in our financial language not going to be material, so don't expect wonders or something coming out big any time soon, we just want to make sure that our partners that we negotiate, like in this case the workers council, are the first ones to hear it and to discuss it and then we'll follow the path.

On OSRAM, I mean, we are very satisfied with the margins and all shareholders, we all think Q2, Q1 was very positive. You see those types of positive developments, those massive drops in margins, if factors are being filled again, there's restocking impact which you will also see internally. You don't want to see it unfortunately, we've seen it about a year ago – I think was also if I'm not mistaken in Q3 and Q4 2009, your revenues drop and then all of the sudden there is also some accounting impact here on that matter, we've seen the same thing now coming back. But a long story short, we are really satisfied with Q2. LED obviously drive margins at the LED business in within OSRAM is accretive to the margins, not necessarily accretive to capital efficiency but at the current level it's accretive to both. So therefore we're actually very pleased and we do expect the LED boom to continue for a few quarters.
Okay.
Okay. So Andreas Willi, JPMorgan.

Thank you. Three hopefully short questions please, the first one a clarification on the restructuring below the sector line, you said 500 million. Does that include what you said earlier on real estate and does that include pick and place as well or not? Second question on minority interest, the minority expense in the P&L dropped quite a bit. We've seen the same at ABB. Does that mean joint venture where you have the majority but still it's the minority interest in China, in India a lot less profitable than they use to be? And third question on NSN, there was talk a while back whether the shareholder loans need to converted. What's the cash position in NSN and kind of the financial outlook there?

Thanks, Andreas. Restructuring clarification below the line that includes that assumption that 500 million assumption you are going to see under that number, it's a four or five number for you to get some orientation what to expect. That includes SIS, it includes the centrally managed portfolio, which is the pick and place, and it also would include real estate if there was any. If we talk about restructuring, we talk about severance, okay. So there is around about 100 million price tag, which we have considered in our guidance for the real estate improvement program, which gives us a 250 million savings already in 2012 and then obviously up to 400 in a few years later, so that would be part of it. But that's not restructuring in terms of severance, or how we called restructuring, but this would be actually capacity adjustments because we put probably consolidate floor pace in order to get the savings later on.

On the minority interest, that's not a systematic development, so if there was any volatility to the good or to the bad that would just reflect the temporary development for a quarter, but for the trend, okay.

On NSN, we did convert major parts of the shareholder loan, we actually converted the first tranche, which was a total €1 billion, 500 million each for the shareholders into equity, and we converted it actually into a sort of equity, which one could call preferred equity in a sense. So that means there is going to be some preferential interest dividend to it. And the second part of the shareholder loan, which is about 500 means 250 each is still with NSN and the shareholders and it is placed and priced at market conditions.

As far as the cash position in NSN concerned, please bear with me the agreement is that Nokia actually goes into the details of its fully consolidated assets. But if I had to answer it, I would probably say all the covenants which are necessary for the cap loans are being secured.
Thank you.
Okay. Martin Prozesky.

Thank you. I've got two questions please. Could you talk a bit about the supply chain program, you didn't mention it today's presentation yet. Are you happy with the progress? I mean, gross margin was up I think 260 basis points on Q2 '09. Just could you give us a sense of how far you are in the program and how much further you expect to go there?

The second one is again on Energy, more specifically on the U.S. and the consolidation of the Canadian facility into the States. What is your expectation for the outfit for mix within the U.S.? And given that the climate change bill that was expected to be passed this week didn't go through, are you still expecting a big gas build-out, wind build-out or how do you expect the U.S. energy markets developing in kind of broad terms?

So let me start with the energy mix question in U.S. first. A; number one, there is no question that the current administration, the President is very committed to this and as we all know this is, at the end of the day, a process which has to go through the House and the Senate. I'm quite hopeful that at the end of the day we will have a bill coming through. The current gas prices would indicate that actually and we see it in terms of demand.
